<p>One really cool feature on the Gulp 4 roadmap is the inclusion of native<br> sourcemaps. A commit roughly two weeks ago at the <a href="git://github.com/wearefractal/vinyl-fs">vinyl-fs</a><br> package makes this possible now. Instead of using the <code>gulp-sourcemaps</code><br> package directly, you can use a flag in <code>gulp.src</code>. Gulp takes care of the rest:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">var gulp = require('gulp'); var less = require('gulp-less'); var minify = require('gulp-minify-css'); var prefix = require('gulp-autoprefixer'); gulp.task('styles', function() { return gulp.src('main.less', { sourcemaps: true }) .pipe(less()) .pipe(minify()) .pipe(prefix()) .pipe(gulp.dest('dist/styles')); }); </code></pre> <p><code>gulp.dest</code> takes care of saving those sourcemaps. So with every <code>gulp.dest</code><br> command, you get new sourcemaps for your output.</p> <p>Under the hood, Gulp still uses the <code>gulp-sourcemaps</code> package. It’s just a<br> much nicer and more direct way of addressing them. Still, your plugins have<br> to “understand” Sourcemaps.</p> <h2>Beta Installation</h2> <p>At the moment, this is still in Beta. To test it, you have to have Gulp 4 installed:</p> <pre><code>npm install --save-dev git://github.com/gulpjs/gulp#4.0 </code></pre> <p>Enter the <code>node_modules/gulp/</code> directory, and install the current <code>vinyl-fs</code><br> package.</p> <pre><code>npm install --save-dev git://github.com/wearefractal/vinyl-fs </code></pre> <p>You won’t have to do this anymore once Gulp 4 is public on NPM.</p> <h2>gulp-sourcemaps</h2> <p>There might be some occasions where you still would need the old plugin.<br> For example, you want to name your source directories to make them easier<br> findable inside your Dev tools. For that, you still have to use the original plugin:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">gulp.task('styles', function() { return gulp.src('main.less') .pipe(sourcemaps.init()) .pipe(less()) .pipe(minify()) .pipe(prefix()) .pipe(sourcemaps.write('.', { sourceRoot: 'css-source' })) .pipe(gulp.dest('dist')); }); </code></pre> <p>It is also necessary, if you want to combine it with other sourcemaps, like those<br> generated by Browserify:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">var browserify = require('browserify'); var gulp = require('gulp'); var source = require('vinyl-source-stream'); var buffer = require('vinyl-buffer'); var uglify = require('gulp-uglify'); var sourcemaps = require('gulp-sourcemaps'); var gutil = require('gulp-util'); gulp.task('javascript', function () { // set up the browserify instance on a task basis var b = browserify({ entries: './entry.js', debug: true }); return b.bundle() .pipe(source('app.js')) .pipe(buffer()) .pipe(sourcemaps.init({loadMaps: true})) // Add transformation tasks to the pipeline here. .pipe(uglify()) .on('error', gutil.log) .pipe(sourcemaps.write('./')) .pipe(gulp.dest('./dist/js/')); }); </code></pre> <p>But since it has the same codebase, you should be fine using them. This is also<br> one of those things that Gulp 4 was constructed on: Things that have proven<br> to be useful, if not mandatory in the past are now getting into core, but still<br> as extractable and reusable as any part of Gulp.</p>
